First time to Chicago and looking forward to checking out more spots next time!

49.description: Founded by jazz musician Fred Anderson in 1982 (who previously ran Birdhouse on the north side), this south side jazz club has been a hot spot for up-and-coming musicians ever since. Early participants include George Lewis, Steve Lacy, Hamid Drake and Chicago's other tenor legend, Von Freeman. During the Chicago Jazz Festival, Velvet Lounge hosts its famous "After Fest" jam sessions that are usually a site (and sound) to behold. There's even a book about it, called The Velvet Lounge:On Late Chicago Jazz by Gerald Majer. Sadly, this location is scheduled to be torn down soon. Massive efforts are underway to raise funds to rebuild Velvet Lounge at a new location at 67 E. Cermak. A historical landmark will be lost, but hopefully the new location will attract a whole new audience.

40.description: Velvet Lounge is a must if you are into the jazz scene.Long story but I wandered here from around Soldier Field one early evening when I was looking for some kind of transit to take me back to the Loop where I was sleeping. Well I come across this place, step in, and it was just perfect. Open session had sweet players, and the audience was surprisingly friendly. House let us bring in outside food (!) and eat there too. Definitely good people there, whether they were looking to play or just hang out. Place was really packed for an open session. Drinks were pretty cheap too. Perfect for the event.

30.description: The fresh fruit Martini's are TO DIE FOR!  Good music and nice atmosphere!

46.description: The original location in Chicago provided arguably the most-defining experience. Fred Anderson is amazing. I caught a show with Hamid Drake a few years ago that really blew me away. I hope this place can survive in it's new location -- I worry about the Starbucksification of jazz in Chicago. Bring cash.

1.description: They are extremely unprofessional.The management is delusional and don't know how to resolve problems. They had the audacity to charge us $96 for a bottle of Sutter Home Chardonny.. Ridic!! They think they are some upscale nightclub to charge $100 for a bottle of Sutter Home Chardonny- Not! Was trying to support a local business but they gouge you on prices and that's unacceptable. Treat your customers with respect and they will come back. We definitely will not be coming back...

9.description: First impression was great!I was invited here by some friends to watch the NBA Playoffs. Half of my friends are Heat fans, and the other half are anti-Miami. I only love the Bulls but for this playoff season I was cheering for the Spurs to kick some Miami ass. Any who... the Velvet Lounge.It's very velvet-y in there. I can't say how it is on your average night, but on this night all the TVs were tuned in to THE game. I don't know how their food is, since the kitchen was closed this night. We all got food from the pizzeria next door and it was good. I like that the lounge let us get food from elsewhere since they weren't serving any. My friends all ordered the "Turn Up" drink which tasted like heavily spiked fruit punch. They were served in small pitchers which I found amusing. It's not a large place. I like the intimacy of it. to the left there is a stage and along the back wall is the bar. Not much to the place. But like I said, it's velvety true to its name.Drinks were good. Food (from next door) was good. Atmosphere was great. I had a great time.

26.description: First impression was great!I was invited here by some friends to watch the NBA Playoffs. Half of my friends are Heat fans, and the other half are anti-Miami. I only love the Bulls but for this playoff season I was cheering for the Spurs to kick some Miami ass. Any who... the Velvet Lounge.It's very velvet-y in there. I can't say how it is on your average night, but on this night all the TVs were tuned in to THE game. I don't know how their food is, since the kitchen was closed this night. We all got food from the pizzeria next door and it was good. I like that the lounge let us get food from elsewhere since they weren't serving any. My friends all ordered the "Turn Up" drink which tasted like heavily spiked fruit punch. They were served in small pitchers which I found amusing. It's not a large place. I like the intimacy of it. to the left there is a stage and along the back wall is the bar. Not much to the place. But like I said, it's velvety true to its name.Drinks were good. Food (from next door) was good. Atmosphere was great. I had a great time.

25.description: The DJ and the vibe on Friday nights is awesome. Highly recommended spot if you like hip-hop and a chill spot.

12.description: Probably the worst experience I had out in a long time.. The bar was filthy, bartenders were not tending to every guest and watching them make drinks were not up to professional standards... The DJ was terrible.. I will never return to this place again.

21.description: This is no longer a jazz/blues place. It was a casual Latin bar/club for a while and now it has a more loungy feel to it and the music is mostly R&B. It's pretty low-key and nothing fancy.

17.description: The music is great the food was great good place to meet yo business entrepreneurs in the DJ moe is a great crowd pleaser

10.description: So I didn't catch the live music.  I was here for a friends Dirty 30 party and it was all you'd want.  The music was poppin, the drinks were good, and the crowd was solid.  A good mix of folks.  As the only guy amongst a group of 8-10 girls, I got to watch more than my fair share of dudes roll up and try to figure out who I was with so they could spit game at the other ones.  They were all polite and respectful and took their rejections in stride hahahaha.  Definitely a good spot if you want to get away from the 20 something crowd but still have a little life left in you.  I'll be back for some of the live music.

5.description: I came to the velvet lounge during a party bus stop for a bachelorette party. The venue is fairly small and with the amount of woman on the party bus we basically filled majority of the lounge.The DJ was the main reasoning for us leaving so soon after arriving. He was terrible. Out of all the 45 minutes of us being there not once did we actually dance, because of the music choice. Their drink specials were a little over priced for them to be drink specials.Although we didn't stay long it seemed like a nice place to go to on a kind of quiet low key kinda night. Definitely not a club atmosphere and if that's what your looking for you might want to go to another place. I might try it out again maybe it will be different since I wouldn't be with a large group. Overall I give this place three stars.

3.description: One of my favorite things to do is listen to live music and Velvet Lounge definitely caters to that. I went on a Thursday evening not knowing what to expect (as I'd only been here on a weekend months ago), but I was pleasantly surprised! The talent was applause-worthy! Singers (male and female) that are from the city of Chicago were the highlight and the band was pretty awesome. Thursday night came with $7 Long Islands. Delicious. Ive honestly never had a bad drink from here to my recollection anyways. The venue itself - love the urban, upscale feel! Tables with white cloths all around, reserved seating areas, and of course, bar space. Get there early as the space can get a little congested. I think I rubbed against some chicks feet walking out because she was stretched out like she was at home. *side eye* Other than that, the crowd is pretty mature and fun-loving. Great place for an evening cap!

35.description: Where you at Velvet Lounge? I hope it reopens soon. I need my Sunday night jam session. I been going to the jam session since they were at 2128-1/2 S. Indiana.

19.description: Pretty cool lounge with intimate space. Dj was playing hip hop music and the crowd was hilarious. Some of the guys there were definitely creepers but thats no complaint on the venue, they just added to the experience. Drinks were average priced $10 and up. The bathroom was unexpectedly small.

28.description: Wonderful place to let your hair down and listen to some great music. Crowd was friendly, wait staff was very attentive ( even when I spilled water all over the floor). I didn't have a chance to sample the mouth watering food..it smelled great. My whole group had a great time..it was "House Night".

45.description: Chicago is a better city because of Fred Anderson and the Velvet Lounge. While I'll forever miss the orange and green wallpaper,  the new location has the same good vibes and fantastic music that made the place legendary. No one should leave Chicago without making a trip here.

33.description: Great place

43.description: Went here recently for one of Mr. Anderson's 80th birthday celebration shows...and I am SO glad I had a chance to see him play the sax. Great music, great people, and decent sound for the space. And the space is hysterical...very VFW. Blue and orange (i think those were the colors) walls, old school vinyl chairs, a few random round tables...It's certainly no Green Mill or Jazz Showcase, and not at all "lounge-ish" but it's absolutely endearing. some cons...The venue is a trek for me, and honestly, I would not have felt comfortable in that neighborhood, had I not had the arm of a strapping young gent to hold on to. However, if you have a car, it's pretty easy to find street parking.It's not cheap (at least the $35 cover that night wasn't), yet the space is not large and they gotta pay the bills, so I get it. There's not a lot of seating or space, so get there early for big names.

2.description: Pretty cool lounge. Music is always nice. It's a small spot so early arrival is suggested if you like sitting. The drinks are ALWAYS strong. I always get the Long Island Iced teas. (Flavored) Raspberry is my preference. Last night they were out so I had watermelon which was tasty too. The bartenders attitudes are so so. Last night we had a guy that was cool. He bought us all shots. NICE. Some nights I've paid $5 to get in, some nights it's free. Dk why. Cool spot 2 go chill I'd say.

18.description: I rsvp'd for it on eventbrite party last Friday night. TIP: The bouncer won't ask if you are there for a party or rsvp'd for an event. He'll just quote you the price to get in unless you SPEAK UP! I'm not shy, so I did, and he pleasantly granted us our free entry. Otherwise it was $10. Reasonable. But free-99 is always better.It was around 11:15/30 so it wasn't too busy. There wasn't a coat check which sucks in Chicago winter. [That's another cash cow opportunity owner! We'd pay for a coat check. We would!] Anyway, the venue isn't very big so within an hour it was packed like sardines in there! The DJ was on point and the vibe was chill. We had such a great time and literally danced the entire night. Drinks were reasonably priced too and it never took too long to get served. I'd check it out again. It's a nice local, chill spot to add to the list if you aren't trying to go too far, pay too much or deal with any drama. I'm with it!

41.description: I was told to go here my first year of college by a math prof I had a crush on, so I may have been biased from the start.However, when I finally spent an evening here I really was amazed, and so sad that I hadn't been there much much earlier.  Three hours listening to jazz here felt like 20min.  It's a small space in a nondescript location with great musicians and no packed loud crowds, which gives it a much more intimate feel than Green Mill up north.  Love.

4.description: Came here for an event last night.  Fairly small venue,  so if you like to sit, get there early.  Got a long Island for $11. It was mixed strongly so I got my monies worth.  I'd like to see how it is during the weekend.

6.description: This place has been here for years but I never had a chance to stop in until this past Friday. I must say that it was definitely a pleasant surprise. Nice upscale bar, limited but comfortable seating, and friendly service.The drinks were very good and reasonable. The lounge area is pretty small but you will definitely have a good time here. The DJ kept the party live.  I will definitely come back.

22.description: Cute spot.  It was early when I went to watch the game.  Had a couple of drinks.  They had good food too.

15.description: My sister and I went to this place on Saturday and was charge $20 to get into this small ass place. We found out later that it only cost us $10 because we were apart of a birthday party. There aren't enough sitting for women who like to wear heels and want to dance. The VIP section is a sectional couch that is divided into 3 sections. The music was horrible and not mixed properly. The manager was nasty when my sister and I were trying to speak to him about the $20 cover charge. I would never go back there again. The best thing about this place was the free parking.I've been to better places besides the Velvet Lounge for less. Anyone that pays $20 to get into this place is dumb. I wasn't expecting to be charge $20 to go into a 4x4 room. I've never paid it before and will never pay it again.

20.description: My 1st, but definitely not last visit to the Velvet Lounge. I went on Tuesday 3/18 for comedy night. $10 charge at the door. Comedy started at 9:30pm. Mix of R&B, neo soul, rap and hip hop music played before and after the show. Wish they would've played some house music for the house heads! The crowd was majority Black, but any race would be comfortable at this venue. The host was soooooo damn funny!!! If you do not want to get talked about, do not sit directly in front of the stage. Our server, Carmen, was GREAT!I had a good time and will be back for open mic night on Wednesdays.

36.description: Great place for jazz, but I wish I had been warned in advance about how expensive the drinks are. I took some friends here and felt bad about how much we all had to pay, between the cover charge and drinks. The music was fantastic though.

14.description: Been here a few times.  The venue is small and often gets crowded depending on what event is going on.  Given the layout and ambiance, I think its a little pricey on the drinks side.  The place isn't much to look at.  But it has some comfortable couch seating if you do manage to get there early enough to snag you one.  One of the things I do like about it is depending on the event, you are allowed to bring food in to eat.  I recently went on a Tuesday for a comedy show and there were a bunch of people with outside food.  And sometimes you may luck out and get a drink special.  But make sure you ask because the bartenders won't tell you.  Same thing with the bouncers at the door.  They may try to get you to pay a cover charge.  So if you RSVP'd for something, make sure you mention it or have something showing you should get in for free.  Otherwise they will try to get you for a cover. Tip: Make sure you ask if it's any specials going on.

3.description: Guys at the bike shop were very friendly. Went above and beyond to help fix an old bike so I could ride it tonight. Very knowledgable. Would recommend for any bike repairs.

1.description: Awesome service, lots of freebies with my purchase. Expert advice, classic and modern rides. Great for families and professionals. Our helper was fantastic so ask for Theo, he's da bomb!

2.description: Best place to get your bike and accessories. They have the newest and best prices around.  I recently got a helmet for my son and the staff person was helpful and understanding.  Lots of selection and great customer service.

0.description: Kozy's helps me when I need it.  But they are as good as they can get because they sold me some nice sun glasses and their price beet amazon prime's price...Enough Said ;)

4.description: Just purchased my new Giant Escape 2 from this new Kozy location.  They have so many bikes available--something for everyone!  I went one day just to look, and then came back for the second visit to make my purchase.  Luis helped me out, and he was very informative about the different bikes and upgrades available without being pushy.  After having my last bike stolen, he told me about a few security options including a special lock for the wheels.  They also have an awesome service plan where if you buy a new bike with them, you can pay an additional $99 for a 4 year plan.  It includes 1 tune up per year as well as many other free service options (basically everything except purchasing new parts, but free labor is HUGE!).  Their regular tune up is $75, so if you do the math, paying $99 up front (no tax on that too!) pays for itself with the second tune up.  Be sure to visit!  Ask for Luis too!

58.description: Nice cozy place, with indoor as well as outdoor seating available. The staff is nice but can be better. The food is good, the falafel are great, as are the tapas. The desserts options are good, but I did not like the baklava there. Have had better. It is a nice place to stop by and try out. Street parking g is available.

56.description: This place is really good. I loved the flavors in the food at Kurah and the food was very authentic. I ordered the hummas and kabab and loved both. The ambiance at the restaurant is surprisingly nice.  I have been to almost every restaurant in the south loop and this was easily the nicest looking one. Very classy looking.

29.description: This is one of my favorite  spots in the south loop. Lovely restaurant, quaint, beautiful decor  with a romantic setting. I am generally disappointed with the design of the ladies rooms in restaurants, but they did it right at Kurah. The ladies room is spacious, beautifully decorated, with a large/ long mirror for you to power your nose and check yourself from head-to-toe before returning to your dining/guests.The owner, Moe is very personable, warm and welcoming to patrons. The staff is very knowledgeable and service is exceptional!  Go for lunch and try the Wap sandwich, reasonably priced and so very delicious! Stuffed with fresh vegetables, succulent chunks of chicken (or other meats and Falafel ) with thin potatoes fries inside...yummy!. Large enough to share, but you will want to take one home. Come back for that romantic dinner  with your partner and try one of their signature drinks...a few selections from their menu:Spaghetti squash has a good zing with the lemon vinaigrette dressing Falafels are crisp, but not dry, seasoned well Lentil soup- robust Bacon wrapped dates, sweet with a smoky bacon tasteTender lamb dishes and well-seasoned herb crusted  salmon- Bon Appetit!Biryani is flavorful  however, it can be a little dry from time-to-time and could use more vegetables Chocolate walnut baklava and bread pudding are my favorite desserts Near Grant park during the festivals and concerts or just walking around the south loop, give Kurah a try, it will not disappoint.

42.description: I had been craving some good Mediterranean food for a little over a week and was looking for a place to go to for a farewell dinner with some friends who were moving out of Chicago.  Had seen this place before a few times riding on the bus and saw that its reviews were pretty high so thought - perfect!  The service was pretty good and I loved the ambiance of the place with the decor being very unique from most other restaurants - it is lovely inside.  As for the food however, overall, it was only okay.  We ordered the falafel, spicy hummus, biryani, lamb and beef rib-eye kabob platter, and the lamb and beef shawerma platter.  The lamb was pretty dry as I thought that they were overcooked, although I did enjoy their chunks of beef.  The vegetables that the platters came with weren't cooked all that well and the rice (even though it's just rice), was only okay as well.  I was really looking forward to finally having some falafel since I hadn't had any in awhile.  They too were only okay.  They were a little harder than I would have liked.  Their hummus was good as well as their pita bread which was soft and warm upon serving it to us.  Basically, we had a whole lot of rice despite having ordered a lot of food for the five of us.  I'm afraid that the food didn't live up to the expectation.

23.description: Came for lunch on Saturday. Loved the quiet but warm atmosphere. The wraps and starters were delicious

47.description: Absolutely enjoyed the food. Great service. Nice ambience.Went here for lunch because Yelp said it was good, and sure it was great.

8.description: There are some restaurants that are a 3.5 star that you round up and give a 4. Kurah is one that is a 3.5 that I round down and give 3 stars and here is why.....We went for dinner on a Fri night at almost 9 and there were diners at 4-5 tables, so fairly empty. They have an Ok drink menu but a full bar makes up for a lack of 'craft' cocktails.  I got a single malt while my wife got a dirty martini. I was at the bar when the server cum hostess cum bartender made it. The olive juice was a pour from the container that has the cherries and olives. I thought that was odd and sure enough, my wife claimed that her proportion was off. For food, we got the bacon wrapped dates, the squash and the combination kebab platter (kefta and ribeye). While the food was well seasoned and cooked right, we weren't wowed by anything. Sadly, we don't feel the need to go back to try other food items since we have so many other places book marked.

31.description: Awesome for vegan options! And our server was so knowledgeable about it as well. The spicy hummus plate is fantastic and the cucumbers and tomatoes that come with it are just as phenomenal. The spaghetti squash was also amazing! Less impressive but still good, were the spinach and onion pies. Overall - awesome

34.description: Let me start with the positives: the sangria and bacon wrapped dates are delicious! Now for the not so great: I also had the spaghetti squash which was way to sweet, my friend got the mussels and there was one out of the whole bowl that was actually done well, the rest as she put it "looked sad".  She then ordered the Zait, Zatar, and Zaitoon because she loves olives and again - they came and "looked sad", I felt so bad for her, the best thing she had was the wine and even that, she had asked for another glass 1/2 way thru dinner and it never came. Then we ordered the chicken shawerma, thinking this was a no brainer - it was the worst shawerma I ever had, not seasoned well and very dry. To add to it, they call it a "shared plate" I ate the whole thing by myself. It was 2 small peppers, an onion, and slice of eggplant with rice and what looked like boiled chicken. There are definitely better options if you are looking for really good Mediterranean food.

16.description: Belly is full, heart is happy. Kurah is great. Just what I have been looking for. Delicious mediterranean/middle eastern tapas, great bar, friendly people, chill vibe. A really nice intimate environment and it is not overbearing/loud/pretentious.

13.description: A couple quick hitter neighborhood Mediterranean reviews while I'm feeling Yelpy. Second up is Kurah, a neighborhood white-linen sit-down spot that ups the ante on price and fanciness versus my earlier review of Pita Heaven.My favorite thing here are the small plates, particularly the hummus. It's excellent, and comes with a few slices of cucumber and tomatoes. If you load up on the pita bread, I daresay you could make a full, light meal right there. Their entree-size dishes are considered shareable and easily feed two despite the high prices. I'm not a huge fan of their red meats, but their chicken is very good. The highlight of the plate is the excellent saffron basmati rice.Someone somewhere (Thrillist, perhaps?) gave major kudos to Kurah's shawerma wraps, but I fail to see the greatness. The pita bread (which you can get with the hummus, natch) is the best part. It's filled with plenty of tasty vegetables, but light on the meat and sauce. There are potatoes in there, which is fine if they're good (think lemon aromatic oven potatoes) but detracting if they're just starchy and dry fries.

11.description: The star of the show here was the delicious (and well priced) muthowma - a creamy flavorful cucumber dip that we adored.  The flatbread was also pretty good, as was the (small) kifta kabob. The bacon wrapped dates were slathered in a super salty sauce that made it impossible to taste any flavor. The sangria was quite tasty. Overall, I'd shy away from the "shared plates" which are not any larger than the tapas selections but more than twice the price. 3-4 tapas selections for two people was plenty for us.

39.description: It's more of 3 and half star restaurent . It's in south side, we usually don't travel on south side. The upside is great ambience , relaxed atmosphere,  cool staff. Service is a little slow but that's expected in a tapas place . Food we ordered 4 small plates and soup . Food was good not extraordinary. Since we had bacon wrapped dates which was sweet we skipped desert and instead ended with Turkish coffee which was highlight. It was different very flavorful and refreshing .

37.description: We enjoyed the Moscow Mule and the recently added Margarita. The bacon wrapped dates were hands down the best either of us every had. Spicy fries were delicious. We shared the lamb and chicken kabobs. All very well cooked. Cheese cake bites, yum. Service was quick.

0.description: Candlelit vision and waft of saffron, the homespun and yet tastefully opulence in decor definitely adds charm to this place. Stone pillars covered with patterns, a marble-topped bar dispensing cocktails, hardwood banisters and dark walnut-colored staircase connecting the two floors, clusters of dew-like bulbs from ceiling. The place was filled with smiles on our Christmas-eve visit. It's very pleasing and lovely when you go through the menu and want to order every item, although you will soon realize you'd have to raise a mortgage if you did exactly. Dishes are made using fresh ingredients and well sourced. We were amazed by the grilled shrimp, where shrimps were used in very simple, effective ways for maximized flavor and smoky aromas. Grape leaved stuffed with creamy rice and beef, imbued with slight bonfire notes. The falafel appetizer was great too. Rather than deep-fried, the croquettes/balls must also have had a awesome brush with flames. Rosewater flan- Different with those previously reported in the business pictures, the flan had a fresh orchid flower on top. Pistachio nuts were missing in the caramelized sugar. Additional egg yolks seemed to manifest in the custard to create more thickness. Will revisit to try more food.

38.description: Great for gluten-free. We've been here a few times. Good service. Fun cocktails. Nice atmosphere (good for a date or for a group - they have a near alcove with a 6 top). Tasty food. We'll be back!

51.description: Pretty meh. Mediocre food for the price. Also, my waitress kept disappearing. I liked some of the decor (e.g., the upstairs area) but other parts of the restaurant weren't decorated enough, making it feel imbalanced.

27.description: Great tapas place, would highly recommend sampling the small plates. The house made cocktails were very fruity and delicious. Service was fast and friendly.

32.description: Darling intimate and beautiful spot in the south loop.  We had: Bacon wrapped dates -- these were exceptionally large! Muthowma -- a delicious light garlic yogurt dip with lemon and olive oil.  Wonderful.  Pita bread was great too.  Birayani -- quite flavorful with raisins and pine nuts.  Excellent. Spinach and feta pies -- a bit doughy and a bit bland but not terrible.Service was fantastic.

54.description: My gf's and I really enjoyed our time here! The restaurant has very cute decor and the food is very tasteful! What to get: Hummus, Fattoush Salad for sure! The pita bread they serve will go great with it!  Oh and don't forget the Kubbeh Tripoli along with the Baba Gannoush. Can't go wrong with what else you mix with those.  One down side, some portions were a tad small for the price and the desserts did not impress :(Regardless, I would def make it back there!

48.description: I ordered takeout here and the food was delicious --I had a kibbeh and flatbread and my friend had the beef skewer. I look forward to dining in here.

44.description: A couple quick hitter neighborhood Mediterranean reviews while I'm feeling Yelpy. Second up is Kurah, a neighborhood white-linen sit-down spot that ups the ante on price and fanciness versus my earlier review of Pita Heaven.My favorite thing here are the small plates, particularly the hummus. It's excellent, and comes with a few slices of cucumber and tomatoes. If you load up on the pita bread, I daresay you could make a full, light meal right there. Their entree-size dishes are considered shareable and easily feed two despite the high prices. I'm not a huge fan of their red meats, but their chicken is very good. The highlight of the plate is the excellent saffron basmati rice.Someone somewhere (Thrillist, perhaps?) gave major kudos to Kurah's shawerma wraps, but I fail to see the greatness. The pita bread (which you can get with the hummus, natch) is the best part. It's filled with plenty of tasty vegetables, but light on the meat and sauce. There are potatoes in there, which is fine if they're good (think lemon aromatic oven potatoes) but detracting if they're just starchy and dry fries.

24.description: The dishes here are done very well and are reasonably priced. This is a great place if you are on a date, craving some Mediterranean fare, or just looking for a good meal on a weeknight.Second the recommendation on the muthowma dip. The kabobs are quite tasty, too. Highly recommend ordering the flan if you can make room for dessert.Tyler was an excellent waiter.

7.description: It was my last day at work so my coworker and I went here to say goodbye. One of my coworkers is allergic to gluten, milk, and chocolate. This is one of the few places that have Gluten-free identified on their menu. She was able to get falafel tapas and eat that. The decor in this restaurant is very beautiful. There are cool patterns along the wall. Llamas in gold spray paint. I thought it was beautiful. I also liked their large windows. I'm a huge fan of natural light (get the Vitamin D going!). The food was great. I got a duck shwarma wrap and it was moist, tender, and well-balanced. The Tahini sauce and the Ghost pepper sauce were amazing, and exactly what the wrap needed. I got rose infused flan for dessert. I thought it was top-notch because the flan was the perfect thickness for me. I didn't taste any rose though, but I thought it was good nonetheless.I thought the service was slow. Our food took a really long time to come out. Also, when we wanted our checks, she took a long time getting it too us and then swiping the card at the register.I went here on a Friday afternoon and the parking was packed. We looked around and eventually just paid $10 for the Columbia University Public Parking lot. It was well worth it since we took a 2.5 hour lunch. That's how much I was ready to leave work. :)

49.description: Excellent food, great quality and friendly staff. Highly recommended if you want a delicious meal at a reasonable price.

40.description: Loving this food! Falafel is the best I've ever had and the spicy hummus is amazing. Sangria is perfect, couldn't be more happy!

53.description: We live very close to Kurah and so it was on my list of places to try for mediterranean food in the neighborhood. Therefore, this past weekend we decided to give this place a try for dinner. It was fairly empty for a Friday night with only 5 to 6 tables occupied. We ordered  spaghetti squash, bacon wrapped dates and a shared platter with rib eye and kefta kebab. Even though the food was well portioned and seasoned, it wasn't worth the great reviews posted on yelp. However, the decor of the place is really pretty with small gold motifs on the wall and an impressive chandelier which adorns the center of the dining space. The service is quick and friendly. But unfortunately, I don't think I will be coming back to this place.

30.description: My sister and I came here for lunch. We had the Mediterranean spaghetti squash, spicy potatoes, a shrimp wrap and a falafel wrap. My sister said the shrimp wrap needed more shrimp, but it had good flavor. Overall, I enjoyed the food and the service and its down the street from my sister's apartment.

46.description: We went on a Saturday for lunch and were the only people there... for the whole time.  I expected that the place would fill up but nope.  Not a soul.  Weird.  The interior is super cute, new, modern and clean.  I really liked it.  The bar looked nice and the industrial drop ceiling was covered in Edison bulbs - really funky, Chicago vibe. But, the food.  It just wasn't there.  The hummus was better than average.  Not great.  Better than good.  The tabbouleh with pom dressing - no.  I shouldve known better.  That dressing shouldn't be on anything. Ever.  Get rid of it.  If you want to add pom to a menu item, add pom seeds.  we had one bite each.  The bacon wrapped dates were sweet enough to be dessert.  The pita was delicious.  The wrap was gigantic (another high point of the meal). It was definitely worth the $12 because 2 of us chomped on it and took 1/2 home. The mussels were full of sand.  All of them.  And that's sad because the sauce was good.  Oh, and my water glass was dirty and the server saw it but filled it with water anyway :( I think there's a lot of promise.  There was another gentleman working and I think he was the owner - he seemed highly invested and he was very nice.

1.description: I would like to give this place a better rating because I really love the food.  But the consistently poor service renders this south loop spot second rate, at best. The past two times I've dined at Kurah, our server has been inexplicably inattentive.  Our appetizers (of bread--yeah, it's not free, you have to order a basket of bread) came out very late. Both times, I had to remind them "hey, bread, yes?" Last night, our bread came after our main courses were delivered.  I was also parched towards the middle of our meal, because he never bothered to refill the water.  We wanted a refill on our bread basket, but he failed to come by to check in on us until we had almost given up and finished the rest of our meal. Ironically, though he rarely made an appearance during our meal, once he'd dropped off the tab, he hovered at the table every few minutes, even though he assure us we could "take our time."The above is not an isolated occurrence at kurah.That being said, they have the best, fluffiest, most delish pita bread I have ever had. Their food is, for the most part, delicious and well prepared. Their menu is varied and has tons of options for all diets--including vegans. So, will I go back? Yes.  But, not as often as I would if they could get their hospitality act together.

55.description: There are some restaurants that are a 3.5 star that you round up and give a 4. Kurah is one that is a 3.5 that I round down and give 3 stars and here is why.....We went for dinner on a Fri night at almost 9 and there were diners at 4-5 tables, so fairly empty. They have an Ok drink menu but a full bar makes up for a lack of 'craft' cocktails.  I got a single malt while my wife got a dirty martini. I was at the bar when the server cum hostess cum bartender made it. The olive juice was a pour from the container that has the cherries and olives. I thought that was odd and sure enough, my wife claimed that her proportion was off. For food, we got the bacon wrapped dates, the squash and the combination kebab platter (kefta and ribeye). While the food was well seasoned and cooked right, we weren't wowed by anything. Sadly, we don't feel the need to go back to try other food items since we have so many other places book marked.

9.description: Darling intimate and beautiful spot in the south loop.  We had: Bacon wrapped dates -- these were exceptionally large! Muthowma -- a delicious light garlic yogurt dip with lemon and olive oil.  Wonderful.  Pita bread was great too.  Birayani -- quite flavorful with raisins and pine nuts.  Excellent. Spinach and feta pies -- a bit doughy and a bit bland but not terrible.Service was fantastic.

26.description: This little gem is tucked away in a corner near 14th and Michigan and is a great place to visit with groups or on a nice date out.  The hummus is savory and the bacon wrapped dates are delicious.  The shawarma options (chicken, beef, etc. and rice plates) and flatbreads are okay but the tapas are what you should go for as there is a good variety and the flavors are great.

25.description: this restaurant is not that good , and it's very expensive, they serve 4 pieces of Kupah for 12 USD !!

12.description: Upscale Lebanese-inspired Mediterranean tapas in the South Loop? YES!We had reservations for 3 at 6:30 but were late and there wasn't too many people inside so we were seated right away. The décor of the restaurant is really interesting. It felt like I was in a middle eastern café, but had a nice modern touch to it. It's a small space but it was used efficiently, yet not uncomfortably. There's an upstairs as well!Our server gave us a run-down of the tapas-style menu and explained how certain items come out in no particular order, and that to get enough food for everyone we should order a lot of different things. She was very helpful and polite, great service!Here's what we had:-Hummus: This was fantastic, hands down probably the best hummus I've ever had anywhere, period!-Falafel: Thick, seasoned well and still piping hot, fresh out of the fryer with a just-as-yummy dipping sauce!-Kifta kabob: Unique spices and flavors with a little kick.-Beef and Lamb Shawarma: Similar to the Kifta above but more mild.-Eggplant flatbread: Also really great, the olive relish was amazing, it reminded me of a light pizza but with more exotic flavors.There was also rice and various veggies served with the two meat dishes, which had a special seasoning on them as well, much better than your average rice accompaniment, I was picking for every last grain on the plate!I tried a recommended Lebanese red wine, the "Massaya" which went great with our meal, it was unusually tasty and I might look into obtaining a bottle for myself!We also had dessert which consisted of Turkish coffee and cheesecake balls. The coffee was very strong, just how it's supposed to be! The cheesecake balls were also decadent.Overall we really enjoyed everything we had. The only problem I have is the price to portion ratio. We spent a little over $30 each after taxes, drinks and tip, but were not exactly full after everything was said and done. If you really want a lot of food here, I do recommend getting at least 1 "shared plate" per person and at least 2-3 other items.Other than that, I thought the food at Kurah was fantastic. Unique Mediterranean cuisine in an upscale setting, I think you will be hard-pressed to find anything similar.I do recommend and will most certainly be back, solid 4/5!

59.description: Went for a lunch date  and shared a lamb/beef wrap and spinach feta pie. It was really good price, flavor  and big portions. It's a plus they are open on Sundays as many loop restaurants are closed. Nice ambiance and good service. If you like spicy get the ghost pepper sauce!

21.description: The flat bread has no surprise, either positive or negative, although the oliver+tomato is kind of genius.Baba gounash is five star. Don't miss it

17.description: Excellent variety and flavors in their menu. Some of the menu items are very authentic (the lentil soup is just like my Lebanese mama makes it!), and some menu items are contemporary/fusion, so there's something for everyone. I will be coming back, especially for the kibbeh. I took away two stars because they are very stingy with the sauces. The kibbeh comes with yogurt sauce and the falafel comes with tahini sauce, but they gave us so little of the sauces (barely a drizzle). Perhaps a spoonful or two would really make these dishes better. Also, the fatoush salad is not very good. They serve you the salad with whole lettuce leaves and a whole tomato cut in half. It's really difficult to eat a salad with uncut vegetables! It's not that hard to cut the vegetables, so this should be an easy for them to fix. We had to cut the salad ourselves during the meal.If they make these little changes I can see Kurah becoming a five-star restaurant!

10.description: The place has a nice vibe, the service is attentive, the prices are not exceedingly expensive, but the food was the star of the night. Everything was delicious. Our favorite was the appetizer: garlic mash. It's a perfect and surprising blend of flavors and textures, served with delicious warm and soft pita bread. My fiancée ordered Duck Shewarma, and I ordered Lamb Kabob. Perfectly cooked, and very savory. Will definitely return some time.

5.description: I have to say, I loved this place! The food was delicious. Their hummus and garlic smash is addicting. I had the quail which came with a delightful pomegranate sauce. I didn't even need a knife the meat was so tender. The grilled Veges and buckwheat were also prepared to perfection. The portions were the perfect amount which was a nice change and ending the meal with Julius Meinl cappuccino was the icing on the cake. I will definitely be back!

3.description: ordered delivery from this place. I dont know why it took so long to order from here as I LOVE mediterranean food, but it was so good. Everything I ordered I loved and I will be ordering from here ALL the time now. It's not necessarily traditional Mediterranean food, however it's been altered in such a good way.  I highly recommend everything I had, the chicken kabobs, the chicken shawarma, the chicken biryani, the assorted appetizer platter, the ghost pepper sauce, the garlic sauce. The wraps are huge, you get your money's worth there. You can tell they make their own pita bread and its the best Ive had in chicago. I cant wait to try more. my personal favorite was the spaghetti squash, with olives and feta. I follow a low carb diet and this did not make me miss pasta at all, it was very hearty. of note: their biryani is on the sweet side, with raisins and almonds, which I loved, however my indian husband was not as excited about it. keep that in mind.

35.description: My wife and I are big fans of Kurah. The hummus is a must and it is accompanied with what may be  the softest and tastiest pita I've ever had. Their kabobs are fantastic as is their falafel sandwich. The last time I was here I ordered the flatbreads for my kids and they were great as well. The restaurant itself is beautifully designed and the vibe is a causal yet elegant space. great restaurant all the way around.

19.description: The flat bread has no surprise, either positive or negative, although the oliver+tomato is kind of genius.Baba gounash is five star. Don't miss it

28.description: The star of the show here was the delicious (and well priced) muthowma - a creamy flavorful cucumber dip that we adored.  The flatbread was also pretty good, as was the (small) kifta kabob. The bacon wrapped dates were slathered in a super salty sauce that made it impossible to taste any flavor. The sangria was quite tasty. Overall, I'd shy away from the "shared plates" which are not any larger than the tapas selections but more than twice the price. 3-4 tapas selections for two people was plenty for us.

45.description: Beautiful ambience and excellent service. The taboulis are to die for. And they always have sangria! I bet the upstairs would be perfect for private parties.

33.description: If you can put up with service with an attitude this may be the place for you. The place was empty but the waiter wanted to put us in a corner next to the bar. In general it smack of problems perhaps of some initial success

43.description: One of those randomly yelp find of mine for a spontaneous dinner with friends on a Saturday night. The moment I walked in, I felt I walked into some ethnic middle eastern world. Took a long half an hour wait although we had a reservation. We ordered almost every dish on the first page of appetizers. Falafel was great tasting, and the best hummus I ever had. My friends rated the bacon wrapped dates and lamb chops are finger licking good. Few of the bad choices were the squash and the stuff grape leaves. I recommend not even both to taste them. Almost forgot, the mussels are a plus as well. Spicy potatoes are nothing but tiny fries but tasted good.

2.description: This review is for their New Year's event. We purchased tickets to their New Year's party/event with a few friends, thinking it would be a great option as they are close to home (no crazy Uber surcharges!) and we liked their food.When we arrived, the tables hadn't been arranged any differently, and it was quite quiet, so it felt like we were just hanging out in a restaurant. Seeing as it IS a restaurant, that wouldn't be weird, but it was New Year's Eve! We were hoping for something more festive than ordering drinks while seated at a table in the corner.The drink menu was limited, which was not advertised but was fine, as everything on there was more or less tasty and good quality. Our opinions really shifted though, when we asked if we could order a small appetizer (sidenote: there were two options: $75 for open bar, or $125 for 4-course meal and open bar - we chose the former). The waitress told us that they only made food for the 4-course package and we couldn't order anything - just drinks. Welp. I'm sure if we had asked management, they likely would have changed their tune, however we didn't bother. I was just surprised that they had no issue with denying someone food - pre-prepared hummus no less! - who plans on drinking $75 worth of booze.In terms of ambience, they didn't dim the lights (we even asked), which sucks, but they had a belly dancer who was lovely and a very nice jazz trio. If the glaring lights had been adjusted, I think it would have felt much cozier and more festive, but that wasn't a huge dealbreaker.The kicker was when we realized it was 11:56 and champagne hadn't yet been passed out. When we asked the waitress, she said it was coming. I walked down at 11:59, tired of waiting, and she shrugged and told me I could just grab a few from the bar. So I trudged back up the stairs with 3 glasses for 4 people as the restaurant patrons were halphazardly counting down (the restaurant didn't do anything for the countdown).My companions and I cheersed a minute late, quickly drank our champagne (which, to their credit, was very good), and remitted to boozing for two more hours.While their food is quite good (I've eaten here before), I would not recommend ever attending a special event here. The staff was not apologetic at all (I even said something about the toast to a manager, and got a "Yeah, it's our first one and we weren't quite prepared" - but no apology) and we left feeling like we had wasted money and the evening.I like this place overall and it's close to home, but I am torn on whether I want to return or not after dropping $75 on a total flop of an evening.To Kurah: I would suggest either skipping out next year, or seriously re-thinking your execution and advertisement of this event.

18.description: I've been here a few times. The food and service are always stellar. On top of that, the decor is lush and beautiful. They even went the extra mile in accommodating a large group a couple of years back for a friend's birthday party. Everything was taken care of, no fuss, and we all had the best time!

41.description: Holy smokes! This is THE BEST of the best Mediterranean spot ever been to! If your in the area definitely stop in, totally worth the time! Fairly priced, stellar service & the best chicken schwarma wrap & hummus!!' A two thumbs up five star kinda place!

52.description: Fantastic food and service.  We are visiting from Dallas and wish this restaurant was back home.  Come visit, you will be uber happy you did.

50.description: Hidden gem!So rude of the South Loop neighborhood to keep this amazing, intimate and personalized experience to themselves.Great food, terrific service and  wonderful people.

4.description: Pleased to find a nice Mediterranean spot close to home!  I came here for a late lunch on a Saturday, and it was pretty empty.  My sister and I ordered the hummus, falafel wrap, and Middle Eastern cheese flatbread.  Our waitress accidentally brought us the falafel instead of the wrap, but in her defense, we were really hungry and decided to just eat the falafel without saying anything.  It was decent but a bit dry.  The hummus and flatbread were better, and pretty delicious.Other than the food, there seemed to only be a few employees present while we were there, but our server was kind and efficient.  The atmosphere of this place is the real treat, though--it's gorgeous!

6.description: This place is DE-LISH-OUS! Delicious! The prices do reflect the quality of food, but I've never had better lamb kabobs in my life! The kifta kabobs were slightly overseasoned, a little too much salt and desperately needed some acid. The garlic smash was one of the most unique things I have tasted, it's a mix of garlic mashed potatoes and a dill yogurt mix, a must try! They have quite a few interesting twists on modern dishes, which makes the food that much more interesting. All in all, I would come back here again, but mostly to try to lamb dishes.

22.description: This place is trying too hard. The food is mediocre at best. My lamb had no flavor, the hummus was grainy, and the service was really slow. I do not recommend it at all.

15.description: I have been to many Middle Eastern restaurants but the cuisine here has a unique and tasty twist!  This has to be one of the best places to go for this cuisine: hands down!It was my first time going and I had no problem with parking since there is a parking lot literally right across the street for $10.  The restaurant is conveniently located right on the corner of Michigan and 14th street.  The decor was nice with beautiful artistic designs on the wall and wide open space.  The restaurant is two floors and has plenty of space with windows that give you an open feel.  I absolutely love it!The customer service is top notch and there is so many options on the menu to choose from.  For our large party, we got a few Kurah sampler dishes, tabouli dishes, a few Kurah platters, and dessert, which was a good variety and plenty of food.  Again, I have had Middle Eastern food a million times but the food here is so flavorful, and unique, I couldn't stop eating! -The tabouli was tangy and tasty.  Highly recommended.-The baba gannoush was smoky flavored and delicious.-The hummous was creamy and perfectly made.-The Chicken and beef shawarma and kabobs were cooked to perfection.  The vegetables were also delicious and complimented the main dish.-DO NOT pass up on dessert!  The rose flan is to die for!  Yummy!I know I will be coming here again.kurahchicago.com/menu/me…

57.description: Good food and easily accessible by the L.

20.description: Kurah is a very nice sit-down Mediterranean place. We went for a quick bite and drink taking a break from the museum. Goat-cheese-stuffed bacon-wrapped dates were delicious.

36.description: I love this small neighborhood spot! The space is inviting and intimate, and service is very polite, efficient, and helpful. By far, my favorite item I have tried is the spicy hummus. This is not your average hummus - the spice is unreal! The falafel is also nice - they're smaller sized falafel, and taste fresh. In one visit, my table also tried the Middle Eastern cheese flatbread, which was decadent, totally unnecessary, but delicious all the same. In other visits, I have tried the tabouli and the ceviche, which were decent but not my favorite. As far as main plates, I've only tried the chicken kabob plate, which I remember tasting fresh and delicious. I have yet to be disappointed in the food! At each visit, my table has ordered carafes of sangria. While the red sangria tastes like your average sangria, I suspect it must be pretty full of juice or whatever they use to make it, and not too full of wine. I always expect to feel a little buzzed, but always end up just feeling full of sugary juice. That said, I have yet to go to Kurah and not order sangria so...Overall, great experience. Keep up the good work!

14.description: Pretty pricey, so my friends and I stuck to getting appetizers. The hummus was delicious and served with warm pita bread. The red lentil soup was delicious, too. I really liked the environment because it had a real Mediterranean vibe. There was an upstairs with more seating.

3.description: Wow! A & L is a spectacular place! From the moment I walked to the moment I left, the people were so kind and welcoming. This is truly a healing studio in mind, body, and soul. They carry art from local artists which supports the community. They also offer art classes, dance classes, yoga classes, and more. I was in town for a conference and badly needed a massage. Leo was so skilled at applying the exact pressure where I needed it. I would highly recommend visiting A & L.

1.description: This place is amazing! L&A has something for everyone. Beautiful jewelry, clothing & artwork from talented local artists. To get your healthy on they offer yoga, pilates & massage. Feeling creative? Try a jewelry making or dance class with Alex. The most knowledgeable and patient teacher ever! Whatever you decide to try, you'll be glad you did! I highly recommend this place.

2.description: Walked past this place one Friday night, and holy smokes was it bustling. A cast of interesting (and friendly) characters walking in, so I made my way in too. (It looked like a private party--- but, nope, all were welcome!)There was music, wine, puppies, and fun conversation. I met who I assumed to be Leo and Alex at the front, checking out some jewelry. Super nice guys.Really neat gifts and treats for yourself. Eyed a killer Chicago flag leather jacket-- but it was out of my range at $350. I still don't fully understand the concept, but I felt good vibes, and saw neat things to buy, so I look forward to being back in the near future.

5.description: Very unique and fun relaxation center/boutique in the neighborhood.  The place has a very peaceful vibe and you can peruse the beautiful jewelry made by local artists and co-owner Alex, aka Monsieur Pamplemousse and various other items such as clothing, art and aromatherapy products.  The space is actually a multi-purpose venue where you can have a massage by a licensed masseur, take jewelry classes (call for availability), hold children's parties and rent out rooms for all things social and creative.  A big plus is that dogs are allowed to roam the store off-leash as long as they're well behaved.  Come down and visit; you can shop, be creative, even just sit for a while and relax.  Alex and Leo will welcome you with a warm smile and help you shake off some of the stress of life..

6.description: A lovely new space & concept, combining a boutique, beautiful jewelry & jewelry-making, classes, a wellness studio & massage. Everyone Is very friendly including the dogs. The massage is fantastic-Mike is truly the best massage therapist I have found during my 20 years in Chicago!

7.description: My favorite little studio in the world! I love all of the beautiful pieces, designs and art. Perfect place to go for all of your essential life needs! Excellent massage and guest service. Next I must attend one of their yoga and craft classes!!

8.description: Amazing little shop with a wonderful vibe in the South Loop! Leo is the best massage therapist I have ever had. I am a full-time hair stylist and need work done regularly. He has been my go to man for the past 5 years, but now he has this WONDERFUL shop for me to come visit him at! They offer everything from massage & yoga, to jewelry making classes & shopping therapy. Alex's jewelry creations  are one of a kind and great quality. They also have a bunch of other local artists work available for purchase as well, such as jewelry, aromatherapy oils, bath salts, clothing, lingerie, and much more! They are my go to guys for a little TLC! ;)

9.description: Gifts, fashion, healing services and friendly customer service. This place is really fun and welcoming. A great boutique for south Michigan Ave. Oh and they teach classes here too. You can take a yoga class or a jewelry making class. Definitely going back!

0.description: I'm all about supporting local Chicago establishments and I decided to check out L&A Healing Studio in one of my favorite parts of the city. I love the South Loop!  Upon arrival you are greeted warmly and I love the comfy feel of the space. The concept is a place to come to for different forms of art therapy. You can buy clothing, accessories, jewelry (and make your own), and bath products. While there you can also partake in a fitness class (Yoga & Pilates). When I was there I decided to try there bath products. OMG the bath bombs are amazing!!! I'm a huge bath person and they smell amazing. I also really enjoy the soaps. On my last visit I decided to get a massage from Leo and two days later I'm still feeling super relaxed! I sit behind a desk all day and my back and neck were really sore, but I left feeling like a new person. This studio has a little bit of everything and I plan on trying out all of the services. Especially in the near future getting a custom made piece of apparel. I love feeling unique and supporting local shops!

4.description: Great little eclectic shop on a quiet part of Michigan Avenue in South Loop. They carry tons of locally designed goods from jewelry to fashion and wood work. There are well priced beads and earrings galore, bath salts, Chicago flag jewelry, and super chic trench coats. Definitely worth a stop for a unique gift.There's an event/studio space too. In the fall they'll have massage and yoga and such. I can't wait to take a jewelry making class there! And did I mention shop doggies?! The two cutest shop pups are there to greet you.

3.description: I have been listening to nothing but blues since returning from Chicago.  I wonder if visiting this place has something to do with that?  The kind of place where you get goosebumps as you stand in the control room or the large recording space where legends played and recorded their classic songs.  If you close your eyes, you can smell the sweat.  Definitely some ghosts lurking around here. The building was in dire need of repair before being completely renovated by the Dixon family.  I believe it was in jeopardy of being completely torn down.  Now, even though it appears as the only real leftovers from the interior of the original building are the control room window space, some Chess Records logos which looked like they were painted on the walls, and some other cool things, there is still a ton of original equipment on display and plenty of displays dedicated to various Chess artists. The tour is led by the grandson of Willie Dixon.  Not only does he look like his grandfather, he knows his music history.  Seems like a good dude...genuine and sincere.  The movie that they play in the beginning of the tour was okay, but long and actually somewhat boring at times, as they really kept saying the same things over and over again.  I am not a huge blues aficionado, just a general music fanatic, so maybe that had something to do with it.  Honestly, it felt awesome just to be in the studio.  As we left the studio, I imagined Little Walter shooting craps on the side of the building, Howlin' Wolf selling his freshly pressed records right outside, and what it must have been like on Michigan Avenue when it was known as "Record Row."Quick note on getting there from The Loop - We hopped on the number 3 bus and got off at 21st Street, almost right in front of the building.  It was about a 25 minute ride due to traffic.  Neighborhood looked fine, although I questioned why during broad daylight you would have to ring a bell and get "buzzed in" to enter the building.

1.description: This was a must see for me in my return trip to Chicago. I was unsure if Chess records was still standing, and did some reading, and found that the family of Willie Dixon had purchased the building, and that his grandson did conduct the tour. We arrived there , and if you appreciate the music that came from this building, the feeling you get when you see this building cannot be described.     Willie's grandson conducts the tour. He is friendly and tells stories about the artists ( Howlin' Wolf, Muddy Waters, Little Walter, Chuck Berry) and then he shows you a documentary.      The museum is filled with pictures, including paintings donated and painted by Rolling Stone, Ron Wood.       There are instruments which were actually used by the artists , including a stand up bass by Willie Dixon.       But what is the most chilling is the control room that Marshall Chess and others stood in and the recording studio. The original equipment is still there. If you love this music like I do, it will give you chills.

2.description: If you're into blues, this is it. The studio and building where almost every classic Chicago blues album was produced, recorded, and distributed. Just the room alone has a great vibe...   the shape of the room, and the natural echo had a lot to do with a great sound that came out of this studio.  Practically every blues legend spent time at this studio under the supervision of Willie Dixon. The tour is casually directed by Willie Dixon's Grandson. If youre expecting a big touristy glitzy experience with the Interactive stations, this is not it. The Dixon family has limited funds but the building is on the National Historic Registry. The Chess name is owned by Universal .Totally enjoyed being in the same space as so many of my Blues heroes.  Go.

5.description: The former Chess Records studio - famously located at 2120 S. Michigan Ave - is a must visit for anyone that is serious about popular music. Would we know rock n roll without the pioneering sounds of Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, or Little Walter? How about without the guitar riffs of Chuck Berry? That Bo Diddley beat? Hell no we wouldn't. Pay homage to the greats and visit Blues Heaven.Chess Studios was spared the urban renewal that has wrecked many southside neighborhoods thanks to the efforts of Willie Dixon's family. Willie Dixon was the poet laureate of Chess, penning too many great sides to name. Blues Heaven Foundation exists to preserve the famous Chess Studios but also offer a musician's perspective on life at Chess. Tours are focused on the players, what their lives were like, and their legacy in American song. The old recording rooms are bare, sound boards probably carted away when Chess moved down the street, but are filled now with a collection of memorabilia. The gear may be gone, but the walls remain, and thankfully we have the Dixon family there to guide us and share stories they heard passed around their home. Blues Heaven Foundation also supports blues artists, providing both performance space in their outdoor theater, as well as financial assistance for musicians struggling with care.Thank the Dixon family for saving this shrine to all that was ever great about music and its ability to connect with people. Michigan Avenue was once known as "record row" with dozens of small labels competing for artists. Many of the great r&b and soul records Chicago is known for throughout the globe were cut on Michigan Ave. Northern soul fans take note: while many are now gone, you can still visit their famous addresses, learned by studying countless 45 labels.

6.description: Love Chicago blues? Well, you don't know a thing until you visit the Chess Record studio at 2120 S. Michigan. The venture south is a departure from the big blues locations often cited as the city's must-sees, but the trip is well worth it. Blues Heaven is a secret haunt intended only for those who know their blues.Warning: This is not a destination suited for the light blues enthusiast, rather a point-of-interest for those familiar with the blues influence and the artists shaped by the musical scribe of Willie Dixon.Dixon's family has driven Blues Heaven for years, so the tour is an ode to his impressive work while also serving as a reminder of the fascinating history of Record Row. There aren't flashy exhibits, just a raw look at the movers and shakers, and a chance to walk the halls that influencers like Etta James, Chuck Berry, Aretha Franklin and Mick Jagger once roamed.My tour was lead by Dixon's kin so the the stories and truths unveiled were fascinating to a young music appreciator like myself (mid-20s). Meanwhile, my in-laws (50ish) were appreciative of the knowledge and thrilled by the rare opportunity.

7.description: Journey back in time to the Chess Record studios where many of the greatest have recorded!  This quiet and unassuming place is well worth a few hours' visit if you are out near Chicago's Chinatown.  The first time I went, the Willie Dixon Blues Heaven Foundation hosted a public program featuring a live jam session in the upstairs recording studio and a blues harmonica lesson (cheesy i know but everyone there was absolutely charmed by this + Mrs. Dixon's inspiring comments)...it was magical to hear the acoustics of live music inside the studio that day.  Returned recently with a group and everyone agreed the magic still reverberates from the walls, even when there isn't a live band playing.  We spent time in the recording studio watching a video montage of interviews and performance snippets from the greatest blues musicians who recorded at Chess, then were free to wander around and check out the control room, lots of memorabilia and the wooden staircases where recording artists hauled their instruments and equipment up and downstairs to record.   a little gift shop area helps with foundation fundraising but they are very low key about sales.  all in all we felt it was well worth the modest admission charge.The staff couldn't have been nicer or more welcoming and patiently answered all questions from visitors.  Kudos to the friendly staffer who stayed late to answer questions from a young local student who was doing research for a class project while we were there.  His stories brought the blues to life and helped cultivate a love and appreciation for the blues that will certainly extend well into the next generation as long as the Blues Heaven Foundation is around.  A very special place!

0.description: A really great experience. Yes, it's only three rooms, but who cares (Sun is only one room!)? This is the place Chuck Berry and Muddy Waters and Bo Diddley recorded some of their biggest hits! And Keith is fantastic. A really sweet kid with some great stories (especially if you ask questions). Thank God for Willie Dixon and the Dixon family for keeping this treasure alive.

4.description: If your time in Chicago is limited, forget one of the "famous" attractions that everyone else goes to and visit the old Chess Records recording studio instead.  It may end up being the most memorable thing that you do while you are there - especially if you were ever a fan of The Blues or blues-inspired rock and roll (The Rolling Stones recorded there early in their careers!)  Be sure and take a formal tour and stay for the lengthy video too.  I recommend that you watch the movie "Cadillac Records" before you go.  Although I learned during the tour that parts of the movie weren't 100% accurate, still, watching it the night before the tour really got me in the mood.
